articles.headline: Loopholes to Some, Lifelines to Others
articles.snippet: Doing away with scores of tax breaks could simplify the tax code and raise money, but it won’t be painless and it might not always be wise.
articles.abstract: Doing away with scores of tax breaks could simplify the tax code and raise money, but it won’t be painless and it might not always be wise.
articles.lead_paragraph: If there is one idea that everybody seems to agree on while peering over the fiscal cliff, it is that we should close the loopholes that riddle the tax code. It is offered as a painless way to raise money, like fixing a leak or ending some unfair privilege.

articles.headline: Fiscal Cliff and Global Troubles Create a Fog for Deal-Making
articles.snippet: For all the talk about the uncertainty of fiscal problems and new financial regulations, the fact is that businesses have long operated in uncertain times, capitalizing on the weakness to uncover opportunities.
articles.abstract: For all the talk about the uncertainty of fiscal problems and new financial regulations, the fact is that businesses have long operated in uncertain times, capitalizing on the weakness to uncover opportunities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street has always been more concept than place. By the late 18th century, a couple of blocks in Lower Manhattan had already become synonymous with stock trading. Later, they became shorthand for the entire American financial system.

articles.headline: U.S. Will Grant Recognition to Syrian Rebels, Obama Says
articles.snippet: Declaring Syria’s opposition as its legitimate representative, marks a new phase of engagement for President Obama in a nearly two-year bloody struggle.
articles.abstract: Declaring Syria’s opposition as its legitimate representative, marks a new phase of engagement for President Obama in a nearly two-year bloody struggle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Tuesday that the United States would formally recognize a coalition of Syrian opposition groups as that country’s legitimate representative, in an attempt to intensify the pressure on President Bashar al-Assad to give up his nearly two-year bloody struggle to stay in power.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Michael R. Gordon and Anne Barnard

articles.headline: In Netflix Case, a Chance to Re-examine Old Rules
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission’s case against Reed Hastings, the Netflix chief executive, over a Facebook post illustrates how the regulator clings to outdated notions of how markets work.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission’s case against Reed Hastings, the Netflix chief executive, over a Facebook post illustrates how the regulator clings to outdated notions of how markets work.
articles.lead_paragraph: Netflix is in the Securities and Exchange Commission’s sights over a post on Facebook by Reed Hastings, its chief executive, saying that the video streaming company’s monthly viewing had reached a billion hours. Yet, the case is more convincing as an illustration of how the regulator clings to outdated notions of how markets work.

articles.headline: North Koreans Launch Rocket in Defiant Act
articles.snippet: Washington and its allies have said they think North Korea’s rocket program has less to do with putting a satellite into orbit than with developing a vehicle for a nuclear warhead.
articles.abstract: Washington and its allies have said they think North Korea’s rocket program has less to do with putting a satellite into orbit than with developing a vehicle for a nuclear warhead.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea launched a long-range rocket on Wednesday morning that appeared to reach as far as the Philippines, an apparent success for the country’s young and untested new leader, Kim Jong-un, and a step toward the nation’s goal of mastering the technology needed to build an intercontinental ballistic missile.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Rate Inquiry Accelerates With Arrests In London
articles.snippet: British authorities have arrested three men in connection with a rate-rigging inquiry, including Thomas Hayes, a former trader at Citigroup and UBS.
articles.abstract: British authorities have arrested three men in connection with a rate-rigging inquiry, including Thomas Hayes, a former trader at Citigroup and UBS.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Mark Scott

articles.headline: China Woos Overseas Companies, Looking for Deals
articles.snippet: With the government’s encouragement, Chinese companies have begun what is expected to be a large number of overseas acquisitions.
articles.abstract: With the government’s encouragement, Chinese companies have begun what is expected to be a large number of overseas acquisitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Even as Wall Street deal makers await a revival of the moribund merger market, Chinese companies are shopping abroad with their wallets out.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Unlikely Backers in a Battle Over Taxes
articles.snippet: As pressure builds to find a compromise for the fiscal impasse in Washington, some of America’s leading executives have dropped opposition to tax increases on the wealthiest.
articles.abstract: As pressure builds to find a compromise for the fiscal impasse in Washington, some of America’s leading executives have dropped opposition to tax increases on the wealthiest.
articles.lead_paragraph: A broad swath of the nation’s leading chief executives dropped its opposition to tax increases on the wealthiest Americans on Tuesday, while the White House quietly pressed Wall Street titans for their support as well.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: That Crush at Kosovo’s Business Door? The Return of U.S. Heroes
articles.snippet: The competing business dealings of former high-ranking United States officials in Kosovo may present a special ethical quandary.
articles.abstract: The competing business dealings of former high-ranking United States officials in Kosovo may present a special ethical quandary.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRISTINA, Kosovo — Prime Minister Hashim Thaci is in a bind. His country’s largest and most lucrative enterprise, the state telecommunications company, is up for sale. The jostling among buyers is intense. Narrowing the bidders has hardly helped.

articles.headline: Syria Uses Scud Missiles in New Effort to Push Back Rebels
articles.snippet: The Syrian leadership may be calculating that it can resort to such lethal arms without fear of intervention partly because Washington has set its “red line” at the use of chemical weapons.
articles.abstract: The Syrian leadership may be calculating that it can resort to such lethal arms without fear of intervention partly because Washington has set its “red line” at the use of chemical weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Bashar al-Assad’s forces have resorted to firing ballistic missiles at rebel fighters inside Syria, Obama administration officials said Wednesday, escalating a nearly two-year-old civil war as the government struggles to slow the momentum of a gaining insurgency.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Textile Makers in Taiwan Create a High-Tech Niche
articles.snippet: The industry has transformed over the past 15 years from low-cost fabric makers to producers of specialized materials.
articles.abstract: The industry has transformed over the past 15 years from low-cost fabric makers to producers of specialized materials.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAIPEI — Jason Chen knows what it feels like for globalization to threaten his family business.
